nodes.bodyText:
That's great, but could be greater : is it possible to pass the session attribute_name and the attribute_session in a req.header ?
With this mecanism, both VScode and WarpStudio can inject meaningful headers automatically, and will be able to abort the current session easily. I already developed the function to stop everything, it will be easy to add a uuid session name at startup, and a request to abort scripts:

Both new headers name should be hardcoded, to avoid too much settings both in Warp 10 and WarpScript tooling.
Keep this default name if there is no headers in request.
Why can't they add a prefix to the WarpScript code they push?

It is more simple than prepend lines, shift line numbers or statement number in error messages. VSCode already does macro inlining and error message transformations, studio does not.
It does not appear in the 'warpscript.script' WarpScript logs.
More flexible to enforce some extra policy later, for example include the user name in each request, or to add a proxy that automatically add the incoming IP or other metadata in attribute_name if a company want to find who is taking all the shared resources. (128 character is a bit too short for that)

You don't need to shift lines as you could very well set the session on the first line without a LF.
Having an alternate way of setting things just for the /exec endpoint brings redundancy and lack of coherency without added value, therefore this will not be added.

Second thoughts, added possibility to set the session via header (but not the name), but disallowed overwriting the session in WSSESSION.
PTAL.
Why isn't session name a property of the stack, just like attribute_name ?

+package io.warp10.script.ext.stackps;
+
+import java.util.HashMap;
+import java.util.Map;
+
+import io.warp10.WarpConfig;
+import io.warp10.script.WarpScriptStackRegistry;
+import io.warp10.warp.sdk.WarpScriptExtension;
+
+public class StackPSWarpScriptExtension extends WarpScriptExtension {
+  /*
+   *  Name of configuration key with the stackps secret. 
+   */
+  public static final String CONF_STACKPS_SECRET = "stackps.secret";
+  
+  /**
+   * Current StackPS Secret
+   */
+  public static String STACKPS_SECRET;  
+
+  public static final String ATTRIBUTE_SESSION = "stackps.session";

nodes.bodyText:
also add session here
result.add(stck.getAttribute(StackPSWarpScriptExtension.ATTRIBUTE_SESSION));

Will be better to replace the list output by a list of map, with keys such as "session_name" "warpscript_name" and so on. It allows greater flexibility in the future, and easier javascript reading for guys who will code frontend.

Missing:
StackPSWarpScriptExtension.ATTRIBUTE_SESSION
(could be relocated in WarpScriptStack maybe ?)

nodes.bodyText: nope since it is added by an extension it is more logical to have it in the extension itself

nodes.bodyText: Missing WarpScriptStackRegistry.unregister(stack) for this registration.
Missing WarpScriptStackRegistry.unregister(stack) for this registration.
Extra spaces to be removed.
stack, not this.stack.
Also, not unregistered but as these stacks are meant to live during all the lifetime of the platform, this is not that important.
I think this.aborted should be reset to false in order to be able to reuse this stack. For instance, UDP or TCP stacks are persistent so aborting a stack will make all subsequent exec early abort.
Aborted stacks should never be reused, this is the whole point of aborting them. Are you suggesting that we should be able to externally STOP a stack on top of being able to abort one?
Ditto.
Missing WarpScriptStackRegistry.unregister(stack) for this registration.
Missing copyright notice.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,95 @@
+package io.warp10.script;

nodes.bodyText: Could fail if a stack has not been unregistered but has been garbage collected.

It would better to create and expose a WarpScriptStackRegistry.getStack(String uuid) to take advantage of the underlying Map.
Also be careful that WeakReference.get() could return null if the stack has not been unregistered but GCed.
It's actually the session name we use to identify the stack, not the UUID, so it is not readily available in the underlying map.
stck can be null if not unregistered and GCed.
Why not simply (String)top?

Why a stack without session name can't be renamed?
At least an error would be welcome instead of silently not setting the session name.
The idea was the opposite, if it already has a session name you cannot change the session name

Wouldn't it be clearer if the two share the same terminology? They effectively do the same but use different info to achieve it.
KILL seems to stop right now the stack, which is not the case, whereas ABORT seems more suited.
Maybe WSABORT and WSABORTSESSION ?
Should we make an exception when aborting its own stack?
use with caution, but no
Same comment as for WSABORT: do we make a specific case for own stack?
use with caution, but no
I think it should be inside the while several line above, not after. It could be added after line 511 for instance.
We should still allow overriding a STOP by a KILL.
So enforce a hierarchy of signals
I find signal() to be confusing, can it be called checkSignal()?
It's not a check, it's a triggering of a buffered signal, so maybe triggerSignal?
Is there a reason this comment is here?
sediment has been cleared
handleSignal already checks this.signaled, so the if can be removed.
Replace with handleSignal();

Because none of the methods are synchronized, there could be stacks in stacks after this registry is disabled.
I think it does not matter that much but as a precaution, I would allow unregister even if it is disabled.
